Privacy-preserving quantum federated learning via gradient hiding

Changhao Li changhao.li@jpmchase.com Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017 USA    Niraj Kumar Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017 USA    Zhixin Song Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017 USA    Shouvanik Chakrabarti Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017 USA    Marco Pistoia Global Technology Applied Research, JPMorgan Chase, New York, NY 10017 USA
Abstract

Distributed quantum computing, particularly distributed quantum machine learning, has gained substantial prominence for its capacity to harness the collective power of distributed quantum resources, transcending the limitations of individual quantum nodes. Meanwhile, the critical concern of privacy within distributed computing protocols remains a significant challenge, particularly in standard classical federated learning (FL) scenarios where data of participating clients is susceptible to leakage via gradient inversion attacks by the server. This paper presents innovative quantum protocols with quantum communication designed to address the FL problem, strengthen privacy measures, and optimize communication efficiency. In contrast to previous works that leverage expressive variational quantum circuits or differential privacy techniques, we consider gradient information concealment using quantum states and propose two distinct FL protocols, one based on private inner-product estimation and the other on incremental learning. These protocols offer substantial advancements in privacy preservation with low communication resources, forging a path toward efficient quantum communication-assisted FL protocols and contributing to the development of secure distributed quantum machine learning, thus addressing critical privacy concerns in the quantum computing era.

I Introduction

Quantum computing has experienced rapid advancements in recent years, and within this dynamic landscape, distributed quantum computing including quantum machine learning (QML) [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9], has garnered considerable attention due to its remarkable capability to harness the collective power of distributed quantum resources, surpassing the limitations of individual quantum nodes. Distributed quantum computation usually involves generating and transmitting quantum states across multiple nodes leveraging the advancements in quantum communication technologies [10]. Remarkably, distributed quantum computing protocols offer a ray of hope in addressing privacy concerns in the presence of adversaries [10, 11, 12, 13, 14], while traditional classical methods have struggled to ensure the confidentiality of sensitive information during distributed processes. These adversaries not only involve third-party attacks that can be tackled with well-celebrated quantum communication technologies such as quantum key distribution [10, 11], but also include privacy concerns with untrusted computing nodes [12, 13].

A critical example of this vulnerability indeed lies in classical federated learning (FL) [15, 16], where multiple clients collaboratively train a machine learning model to optimize a given task while keeping their training data distributed without being moved to a single server or data center. A central server is assigned the responsibility of aggregating the client model updates, typically the model cost function gradients generated by the clients using their local data. However, this opens up a possibility of leaking client’s sensitive data to the server using gradient inversion attacks [17, 18, 19, 20, 21]. While techniques employing homomorphic encryption or differential privacy [22, 23] have been introduced to tackle the problem, they usually demand additional computational and communication overhead or come at the expense of reduced model accuracy. To this end, quantum technologies could provide a natural embedding of privacy. To counteract the gradient inversion attack, one recent proposal [9] replaced the classical neural network in the FL model with variational quantum circuits built using expressive quantum feature maps such that the problem of a successful attack is reduced to solving high-degree multivariate Chebyshev equations. Other quantum-based proposals include adding a certain level of noise to the gradient values to reduce the probability of a successful gradient inversion attack [24], leveraging blind quantum computing [25], and others [26, 27, 28, 29]. An alternative to the aforementioned methods is to encode the client’s classical gradient values into quantum states and leverage quantum communication between the clients and server to transmit the states. This provides opportunities to hide the gradient values of individual clients from the server while allowing the server to perform the model aggregation using appropriate quantum operations on their end. In this case, the transmitted quantum states offer an inherent advantage in terms of privacy even without additional privacy mechanisms, as the classical information can be encoded in logarithmic number of qubits and using Holevo’s bound, the server could extract at most logarithmic number bits of classical information during each round of communication [6]. Moreover, we remark that the approach can be naturally integrated with quantum cryptographic techniques [30, 10] to become robust against third-party attacks.

In this work, we introduce protocols for the above approach, aiming to advance the capability of distributed quantum computing with quantum communication in the context of FL. Specifically, we propose two types of protocols: one based on private inner-product estimation to perform model aggregation, and the other based on the concept of incremental learning to encode the model aggregated sum in the phase of the quantum state. For the former, we transform the secure model aggregation task into a correlation estimation problem and generalize the recently-developed blind quantum bipartite correlator (BQBC) algorithm [7] into multi-party scenarios. For m𝑚m clients with d𝑑d model parameters to be updated, the protocol involves a quantum communication cost of 𝒪~​(m​d/ϵ)~𝒪𝑚𝑑italic-ϵ\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(md/\epsilon) where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the standard model update error, and it is quadratically better in m𝑚m compared to the analogous method based on classical secret sharing [31]. For the second type of protocol, similar to incremental learning, clients perform multi-party computation sequentially or simultaneously without having the server involved until the end of the protocol at which the server extracts the aggregated gradient information. For one of our proposed protocols within the framework of incremental learning, the secure multi-party summation algorithm achieves a similar quantum communication cost as the BQBC with the complexity being 𝒪~​(m​d/ϵ)~𝒪𝑚𝑑italic-ϵ\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(md/\epsilon).

These protocols are designed not only to bolster privacy but also to have an evaluation on the quantum communication costs. Through the application of quantum algorithms, this work aspires to unlock novel strategies that are capable of safeguarding sensitive information within the realm of distributed quantum computing while optimizing communication efficiency. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the suggested protocols can seamlessly integrate with quantum key distribution protocols, thereby ensuring information-theoretic security against external eavesdropper attacks. Our work sheds light on designing efficient quantum communication-assisted federated learning algorithms and paves the way for secure distributed quantum machine learning protocols.

II Problem Statement

II.1 Federated Learning setup

We present the settings of the quantum communication-based federated learning scheme involving m𝑚m clients and a central server. Consider the setup with each client i∈[m]𝑖delimited-[]𝑚i\in[m] having Nisubscript𝑁𝑖N_{i} samples of the form,

𝐗(i),Y(i):{(𝐱j(i),yj(i))}j=1Ni,i∈[m]:superscript𝐗𝑖superscript𝑌𝑖superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖𝑗𝑗1subscript𝑁𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\mathbf{X}^{(i)},Y^{(i)}:\{(\mathbf{x}^{(i)}_{j},y^{(i)}_{j})\}_{j=1}^{N_{i}},\hskip 5.69054pti\in[m]

such that the total number of samples across all the clients is N=∑i∈[m]Ni𝑁subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝑁𝑖N=\sum_{i\in[m]}N_{i}. Here each 𝐱j(i)∈ℝnsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑗𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbf{x}_{j}^{(i)}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and yj(i)∈𝒞superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑗𝑖𝒞y_{j}^{(i)}\in\mathcal{C} for finite set of output classes.

The aim is to learn a single, global statistical model such that the client data is processed and stored locally, with only the intermediate model updates being communicated periodically with a central server. In particular, the goal is typically to minimize a central objective cost function,

min𝜽​[𝓛​(𝜽)=∑i=1mwi​𝓛i​(𝜽)]subscriptmin𝜽delimited-[]𝓛𝜽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝓛𝑖𝜽\text{min}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left[\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\sum_{i=1}^{m}w_{i}\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right] (1)

where 𝜽={θ1,⋯,θd}∈ℝd𝜽subscript𝜃1⋯subscript𝜃𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}=\{\theta_{1},\cdots,\theta_{d}\}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} are the set of d𝑑d trainable parameters of the FL model. The user-defined term wi≥0subscript𝑤𝑖0w_{i}\geq 0 determines the relative impact of each client in the global minimization procedure with the most natural setting being wi=NiNsubscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖𝑁w_{i}=\frac{N_{i}}{N}. That is, here the weight wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} depends on the local data size of individual clients and is known to both the server and clients.

In the standard federated learning setup, at the t𝑡t-th iteration, the clients each receive the parameter values 𝜽t∈ℝdsuperscript𝜽𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} from the server and their task is to compute the gradients with respect to 𝜽tsuperscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t} and send it back to the server. Here the superscript denotes the iteration step. Upon performing a single batch training, they compute the d𝑑d gradient updates ∇𝓛i∇subscript𝓛𝑖\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{i} and share it with the server. The server’s task is then to perform the gradient aggregation within a standard error bound ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon to update the next set of parameters 𝜽t+1superscript𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t+1} using the rule,

𝜽t+1=𝜽t−α​∑i=1mwi​∇𝓛i​(𝜽𝒕),superscript𝜽𝑡1superscript𝜽𝑡𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑤𝑖∇subscript𝓛𝑖superscript𝜽𝒕\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t+1}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t}-\alpha\sum_{i=1}^{m}w_{i}\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}}), (2)

where for the rest of the work, we assume the relative impact wi=NiNsubscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑁𝑖𝑁w_{i}=\frac{N_{i}}{N}, and α𝛼\alpha is the learning rate hyperparameter chosen by the server. The parameters 𝜽t+1superscript𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{t+1} are then communicated back to the clients and the protocol repeats until a desired stopping criteria is reached.

We denote that in many cases, one is interested in learning ∑i=1m∇𝓛i​(𝜽𝒕)mod2​πmodulosuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚∇subscript𝓛𝑖superscript𝜽𝒕2𝜋\sum_{i=1}^{m}\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}})\mod 2\pi as the model parameters can have a 2​π2𝜋2\pi period, particularly in quantum circuits. We point out that here the local circuit model of both the server and clients could be either classical or quantum, but they both have the capability of encoding their local data into quantum states. Further, we consider a quantum communication channel between the server and m𝑚m clients in order to facilitate the transmission of quantum states.

II.2 Data leakage in classical FL

The existing classical FL setup was built on the premise that sharing gradients to the server would not leak the local data information to the server. However, this notion of privacy has been challenged by the wider community [19]. Specifically led by the work of [20] and followed up by [17, 32, 33, 34], it’s shown that it is possible for the honest-but-curious server (who strictly follows the protocol but is interested in learning clients’ private data) to extract input data from model gradients. In fact, using the results of [18], we showcase in Appendix A how to easily invert the gradients generated from a fully connected neural network model to learn the data.

While classical techniques including homomorphic encryption [22] and secret sharing [31] have been employed to tackle the challenge, they usually impose a significant overhead in communication and computation cost, limiting their applications for federated learning tasks. On the other hand, randomization approach employing differential privacy [23], while being simple to implement, usually leads to a reduced model accuracy and utility (see Appendix B for details).

In this work, we address the concern of data leakage originating from gradients that are generated by either a classical neural network based model or a variational quantum circuit based model [35]. The primary objective is to facilitate a secure global parameter update without divulging individual clients’ gradient information ∇𝓛i​(𝜽𝒕)∇subscript𝓛𝑖superscript𝜽𝒕\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}}) to the server, thereby mitigating the risk of gradient inversion attacks. In order to hide the individual gradient information while still performing the model parameter update in Eq. 2, one can implement privacy in either multiplication between weights wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} and local gradient ∇𝓛i​(𝜽𝒕)∇subscript𝓛𝑖superscript𝜽𝒕\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}}) , or summation among weighted gradients. In what followings, we will show protocols along these two ways: secure inner product estimation or secure weighted gradient summation (in analogy with incremental learning). Before diving into the details, we summarize the proposed protocols by listing the main privacy mechanism as well as quantum communication complexity and their requirements in Table 1.

III Protocol I: secure inner product estimation

In this section, we consider converting the model aggregation problem into task of distributed inner product estimation between server and clients where algorithms such as quantum bipartite correlator (QBC) [8, 7] could be employed. From the federated learning parameter update rule Eq. 2, we note that for each parameter index, j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d], the task for the server would be to perform multiplication between the weight wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i} and local gradient ∇ℒi,j​(𝜽)∇subscriptℒ𝑖𝑗𝜽\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i,j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), before summation of all weighted gradients to obtain θjt+1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑗𝑡1\theta_{j}^{t+1}.

In the following, we start from a baseline approach where the secure inner product is performed with the assistance of classical secret sharing (CSS). Following it, we utilize the blind quantum bipartite correlator algorithm and propose a scheme for secure inner product estimation with quadratically fewer communication cost in m𝑚m.

III.1 Baseline: Classical secret sharing assisted inner-product estimation

In this section, we start with a purely classical strategy to hide the gradients of the clients prior to sending the masked gradients to the server. We use this as a baseline to compare against the quantum gradient hiding strategies we develop over the next sections. The baseline strategy is built using the masking technique with one-time pads as introduced in Protocol 0 in Ref. [31]. For this protocol to succeed, we assume that each client is switched “on” during the entirety of the protocol and further, has pairwise secure classical communication channels with each of the m−1𝑚1m-1 other clients.

The protocol starts with each client i𝑖i sampling m−1𝑚1m-1 random values si,k∈[0,R)subscript𝑠𝑖𝑘0𝑅s_{i,k}\in[0,R) for every other client indexed by k𝑘k. Here R𝑅R is the chosen upper limit of the interval as agreed by all the clients. Similarly, all other clients generate the random values in [0,R)0𝑅[0,R) for every other client. Next, clients i𝑖i and k𝑘k exchange si,ksubscript𝑠𝑖𝑘s_{i,k} and sk,isubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖s_{k,i} over their secure channel and compute the perturbations pi,k=si,k−sk,i​(mod​R)subscript𝑝𝑖𝑘subscript𝑠𝑖𝑘subscript𝑠𝑘𝑖mod𝑅p_{i,k}=s_{i,k}-s_{k,i}(\text{mod}~{}R). We note that pi,k=−pk,isubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘𝑖p_{i,k}=-p_{k,i}, Further, pi,k=0subscript𝑝𝑖𝑘0p_{i,k}=0 when i=k𝑖𝑘i=k. The clients repeat the above procedure a total of d𝑑d times (to mask each of the d𝑑d gradient values ∇ℒi,j​(𝜽)∇subscriptℒ𝑖𝑗𝜽\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i,j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})).

Next, for every parameter to be updated, each client sends masked gradient value to the server,

yi=∇ℒi​(𝜽)+1wi​∑k=1mpi,k​(mod​R).subscript𝑦𝑖∇subscriptℒ𝑖𝜽1subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚subscript𝑝𝑖𝑘mod𝑅y_{i}=\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\frac{1}{w_{i}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}p_{i,k}(\text{mod}~{}R). (3)

Note that we drop the parameter index j𝑗j hereafter for simplicity. The task of the server is then to perform a weighted aggregation of the gradients in order to obtain the next set of parameter values. It can be trivially checked that an honest server always succeeds in performing the correct aggregation, i.e.,

y¯=∑i=1mwi​yi=∑i=1mwi​∇ℒi​(𝜽)+∑i,k(si,k−sk,i)​(mod​R)=∑i=1mwi​∇ℒi​(𝜽).¯𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑤𝑖∇subscriptℒ𝑖𝜽subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝑠𝑖𝑘subscript𝑠𝑘𝑖mod𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑤𝑖∇subscriptℒ𝑖𝜽\begin{split}\bar{y}&=\sum_{i=1}^{m}w_{i}y_{i}\\ &=\sum_{i=1}^{m}w_{i}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+\sum_{i,k}(s_{i,k}-s_{k,i})(\text{mod}~{}R)\\ &=\sum_{i=1}^{m}w_{i}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}).\end{split} (4)

Further, privacy is guaranteed due to the use of one-time pad masking of gradients which guarantees information-theoretic security against malicious server.

The above scheme requires a total of m​(m−1)2×d​log⁡(R)≈𝒪​(m2​d)𝑚𝑚12𝑑𝑅𝒪superscript𝑚2𝑑\frac{m(m-1)}{2}\times d\log(R)\approx\mathcal{O}(m^{2}d) classical bits of communication between the clients and a further 𝒪​(m​d)𝒪𝑚𝑑\mathcal{O}(md) bits of communication between the clients and server to achieve secure aggregation. Thus the total classical communication complexity required is,

𝒞C​S​SC=𝒪​((m+m2)​d)≈𝒪​(m2​d).superscriptsubscript𝒞𝐶𝑆𝑆𝐶𝒪𝑚superscript𝑚2𝑑𝒪superscript𝑚2𝑑\mathcal{C}_{CSS}^{C}=\mathcal{O}((m+m^{2})d)\approx\mathcal{O}(m^{2}d). (5)

We remark that the above classical secret sharing based scheme could be augmented using quantum resources to provide a minor improvement in the total communication cost (Fig. 1a). Specifically, after obtaining the masked gradients as in Eq. 3, the clients can collaboratively encode their masked gradients in an amplitude encoded quantum state,

The total communication complexity with this scheme is,

𝒞C​S​SQ=𝒪​((log⁡mϵ2+m2)​d).superscriptsubscript𝒞𝐶𝑆𝑆𝑄𝒪𝑚superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝑚2𝑑\mathcal{C}_{CSS}^{Q}=\mathcal{O}\left(\left(\frac{\log m}{\epsilon^{2}}+m^{2}\right)d\right). (7)

III.2 Model aggregation with blind quantum bipartite correlator algorithm

To reduce the communication cost, in this section, we propose a method for model updating based on quantum bipartite correlator algorithm [8, 7] that is designed to estimate inner product between remote vectors. The essential idea is a generalization of recently-proposed blind quantum bipartite correlator algorithm [7]: firstly, each client converts the gradient information into binary floating point numbers. Then, at each round of communication, the server passes the index qubit state that encodes weight information into each honest or honest-but-curious client and let them privately encode the gradient information into the phase of corresponding index qubits. Finally, the server receives back the index qubits and perform quantum counting algorithm to extract the desired aggregated gradient.

We now proceed to the implementations details of the algorithm. As mentioned, the goal is to have the sever performs the inner product estimation using the known weight information and gradient information that is only locally held by each client. For the k𝑘k-th client (k∈[m]𝑘delimited-[]𝑚k\in[m]), both the weight wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} and the gradient ∇𝓛k∇subscript𝓛𝑘\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{k} can be expanded as binary bitstrings both with size lksubscript𝑙𝑘l_{k}: 𝒂ksubscript𝒂𝑘\boldsymbol{a}_{k} and 𝒃ksubscript𝒃𝑘\boldsymbol{b}_{k}, such that wk⋅∇𝓛k⋅subscript𝑤𝑘∇subscript𝓛𝑘w_{k}\cdot\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{k} equals to the inner product lk​1lk​∑jak​j​bk​j=lk​ak​bk¯subscript𝑙𝑘1subscript𝑙𝑘subscript𝑗subscript𝑎𝑘𝑗subscript𝑏𝑘𝑗subscript𝑙𝑘¯subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘l_{k}\frac{1}{l_{k}}\sum_{j}a_{kj}b_{kj}=l_{k}\overline{a_{k}b_{k}}. One example of such expansions is to use the IEEE standard for floating-point arithmetic [37], where we can have

wk=∑i=0lk2u−i​ak​i,∇𝓛k=∑i=0lk2v−i​bk​i.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑤𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖0subscript𝑙𝑘superscript2𝑢𝑖subscript𝑎𝑘𝑖∇subscript𝓛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖0subscript𝑙𝑘superscript2𝑣𝑖subscript𝑏𝑘𝑖w_{k}=\sum_{i=0}^{l_{k}}2^{u-i}a_{ki},\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{k}=\sum_{i=0}^{l_{k}}2^{v-i}b_{ki}. where the index k𝑘k denotes the k𝑘k-th client and index i𝑖i is the index for bitstring with size l0subscript𝑙0l_{0}. We omit the normalization factor for above and following states in the protocol for simplicity.

Then, as shown in the diagram in Fig. 1b, the server delivers the above ⌈log⁡(m​l0)⌉+1𝑚subscript𝑙01\lceil\log(ml_{0})\rceil+1 qubits to the first client. Note that a malicious server could prepare a state ∑k=1m∑i=1l0ck​i​|k,i⟩​|ak​i⟩oasuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑙0subscript𝑐𝑘𝑖ket𝑘𝑖subscriptketsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖subscript𝑜𝑎\sum_{k=1}^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{l_{0}}c_{ki}\ket{k,i}\ket{a_{ki}}_{o_{a}} with non-uniform amplitude distribution of ck​isubscript𝑐𝑘𝑖c_{ki} to extract clients’ information of interest. To detect such attacks, the first client would firstly decode the ancillary qubit oasubscript𝑜𝑎o_{a} (as the encoded weight information is known globally) and then measure the index qubits in X𝑋X basis. In the honest server case where ck​isubscript𝑐𝑘𝑖c_{ki} has a uniform distribution, measurement outcome should be all +1. That is, if a malicious server tries to extract certain gradient information by increasing the amplitude of corresponding bitstrings, the index qubit state without the ancilla would not be |+⟩⊗⌈log⁡(m​l0)⌉superscriptkettensor-productabsent𝑚subscript𝑙0\ket{+}^{\otimes\lceil\log(ml_{0})\rceil}.

After successful verification and re-encoding of the weight information in ancillary qubit oasubscript𝑜𝑎o_{a} , the first client encodes its local gradient information ∇𝓛1∇subscript𝓛1\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{1} into the phase of the first part of index qubits, which leads to

∑i=1l0(−1)a1​i​b1​i​|1,i⟩​|a1​i⟩oa+∑k=2m∑i=1l0|k,i⟩​|ak​i⟩oa.superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑙0superscript1subscript𝑎1𝑖subscript𝑏1𝑖ket1𝑖subscriptketsubscript𝑎1𝑖subscript𝑜𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑘2𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑙0ket𝑘𝑖subscriptketsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖subscript𝑜𝑎\sum_{i=1}^{l_{0}}(-1)^{a_{1i}b_{1i}}\ket{1,i}\ket{a_{1i}}_{o_{a}}+\sum_{k=2}^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{l_{0}}\ket{k,i}\ket{a_{ki}}_{o_{a}}. (11)

This could be done using CZ gate between qubit oasubscript𝑜𝑎o_{a} and a local qubit held by the first client that encodes ∇𝓛1∇subscript𝓛1\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{1}.

The first client then passes the above state to the second client, who then encodes its local gradient information ∇𝓛2∇subscript𝓛2\nabla\boldsymbol{\mathcal{L}}_{2} into the phase of the second part of index qubits. The resulting state is

∑i=1l0(−1)a1​i​b1​i​|1,i⟩​|a1​i⟩oa+∑i=1l0(−1)a2​i​b2​i​|2,i⟩​|a2​i⟩oa+∑k=3m∑i=1l0|k,i⟩​|ak​i⟩oasuperscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑙0superscript1subscript𝑎1𝑖subscript𝑏1𝑖ket1𝑖subscriptketsubscript𝑎1𝑖subscript𝑜𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑙0superscript1subscript𝑎2𝑖subscript𝑏2𝑖ket2𝑖subscriptketsubscript𝑎2𝑖subscript𝑜𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑘3𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑙0ket𝑘𝑖subscriptketsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖subscript𝑜𝑎\begin{split}\sum_{i=1}^{l_{0}}(-1)^{a_{1i}b_{1i}}\ket{1,i}\ket{a_{1i}}_{o_{a}}+&\sum_{i=1}^{l_{0}}(-1)^{a_{2i}b_{2i}}\ket{2,i}\ket{a_{2i}}_{o_{a}}\\ +&\sum_{k=3}^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{l_{0}}\ket{k,i}\ket{a_{ki}}_{o_{a}}\\ \end{split} (12)

The above process is repeated until all the clients have encoded their local gradient information in the phase, resulting to a state

∑k=1m∑i=1l0(−1)ak​i​bk​i​|k,i⟩​|ak​i⟩oa.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑙0superscript1subscript𝑎𝑘𝑖subscript𝑏𝑘𝑖ket𝑘𝑖subscriptketsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖subscript𝑜𝑎\sum_{k=1}^{m}\sum_{i=1}^{l_{0}}(-1)^{a_{ki}b_{ki}}\ket{k,i}\ket{a_{ki}}_{o_{a}}. (13)

Finally, the state is returned to the server by the last client. Then the server runs quantum counting algorithm [8, 7] to evaluate 1m​l0​∑k=1m∑j=1l0ak​j​bk​j=1m​∑k=1mak​bk¯1𝑚subscript𝑙0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑙0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑗subscript𝑏𝑘𝑗1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚¯subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘\frac{1}{ml_{0}}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\sum_{j=1}^{l_{0}}a_{kj}b_{kj}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\overline{a_{k}b_{k}}. In order to perform the estimation algorithm, 𝒪​(1ϵ)𝒪1italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon}) rounds of communication is needed where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the standard estimation error. We remark that quantum counting algorithm is based on Grover’s search algorithm and is advantageous compared with SWAP-test based algorithms [38] in terms of the error complexity.

We present the takeaway of this method here. Firstly, the privacy is encode in the index qubit states. When the server measures the index qubits, the probability of getting a specific index is simple 1m​l01𝑚subscript𝑙0\frac{1}{ml_{0}}, which is small when client number m𝑚m is large. Moreover, the server could not amplify the amplitude of a specific index by preparing a uniformly distributed superposition state, as the first client is capable of verifying it. Furthermore, even there are multi-round of communication and the server could perform collective attack, by increasing l0subscript𝑙0l_{0} or adding a random pad on the phase, it’s still hard for the server to get individual client’s information [7]. Note that here the privacy comes from the phase encoding, rather than summation of gradients as in incremental learning protocols.

The quantum communication complexity would be the total number of qubits transmitted in order to estimate 1m​∑k=1mak​bk¯1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚¯subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘\frac{1}{m}\sum_{k=1}^{m}\overline{a_{k}b_{k}} in the protocol, which reads as

𝒞B​Q​B​C=𝒪​(m​d​log⁡(m​l0)ϵ)=𝒪​(m​dϵ​log⁡(m​log⁡(mϵ))).subscript𝒞𝐵𝑄𝐵𝐶𝒪𝑚𝑑𝑚subscript𝑙0italic-ϵ𝒪𝑚𝑑italic-ϵ𝑚𝑚italic-ϵ\mathcal{C}_{BQBC}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{md\log(ml_{0})}{\epsilon})=\mathcal{O}(\frac{md}{\epsilon}\log(m\log(\frac{m}{\epsilon}))). (14)

Again, here m𝑚m is the number of clients, and l0subscript𝑙0l_{0} is related with the precision of gradient m​l0=O​(m​log⁡(1/ϵ0))=O​(m​log⁡(m/ϵ))𝑚subscript𝑙0𝑂𝑚1subscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑂𝑚𝑚italic-ϵml_{0}=O(m\log(1/\epsilon_{0}))=O(m\log(m/\epsilon)) where ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0} is the inner product estimation error bound for single clients. This is better than classical secret sharing which has a total complexity in O​(m2)𝑂superscript𝑚2O(m^{2}). We note that in the absence of random phase padding, the technique here doesn’t require classical communication at each round. The incorporation of random, one-time phase pads for privacy enhancement necessitates an additional classical communication cost of 𝒪~​(m)~𝒪𝑚\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(m), as each client would need to send the padding information to the server at last.

III.3 Redundant encoding

The privacy of the protocol above could be further enhanced with redundant encoding of gradient data into binary bitstrings [7]. In particular, we remark on the following theorem:

Theorem 1 (Efficient redundant encoding).

In the BQBC-based QFL protocol, given a fixed estimation error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, there exists a redundant encoding method with a redundant parameter r𝑟r, such that the probability that server learns client’s information decrease polynomially in r𝑟r, which the communication complexity increases only poly-logarithmically in r𝑟r.

Proof.

Following Ref. [7], we consider the following redundant encoding approach aimed at reducing the probability that a malicious server acquiring a specific bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} information with i𝑖i being the pertinent index of interest. we describe the following protocol where both the client k𝑘k and server encode their single bit local information bk​isubscript𝑏𝑘𝑖b_{ki} and ak​isubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖a_{ki} into bitstrings [bk​i,1′,bk​i,2′,⋯,bk​i,r′]subscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑘𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑘𝑖2⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑏′𝑘𝑖𝑟{\left[b^{\prime}_{ki,1},b^{\prime}_{ki,2},\cdots,b^{\prime}_{ki,r}\right]} and [ak​i,1′,ak​i,2′,⋯,ak​i,r′]subscriptsuperscript𝑎′𝑘𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝑎′𝑘𝑖2⋯subscriptsuperscript𝑎′𝑘𝑖𝑟{\left[a^{\prime}_{ki,1},a^{\prime}_{ki,2},\cdots,a^{\prime}_{ki,r}\right]} with size r𝑟r, where r𝑟r is an integer and r>1𝑟1r>1. The total amount of bits then increases from m​l0𝑚subscript𝑙0ml_{0} to r​m​l0𝑟𝑚subscript𝑙0rml_{0}. For the weight information, we consider the following encoding rule

𝒂k​i,j′=ak​i;k=1,2,…,m;i=1,2,…,l0;j=1,2,…,r;\begin{split}\boldsymbol{a}^{\prime}_{ki,j}=a_{ki};\quad k=1,2,...,m;i=1,2,...,l_{0};j=1,2,...,r;\end{split} (15)

which is a simply copy the bit ak​isubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖a_{ki} for r𝑟r times. Here k𝑘k is the index for client and i𝑖i is the index of bitstring held by each client.

On the other hand, for 𝒃k′subscriptsuperscript𝒃′𝑘\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime}_{k}, the k𝑘k-th client can hide the information bk​isubscript𝑏𝑘𝑖b_{ki} randomly in one of the r𝑟r digits and let the other r−1𝑟1r-1 digits to be all zero or one. That is, for bit index i𝑖i, the k𝑘k-th client chooses either

𝒃k​i,j′=δj,Rk​i⋅bk​i;i=1,2,…,l0;j=1,2,…,r,Rk​i∈{1,2,…,r}.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝒃′𝑘𝑖𝑗⋅subscript𝛿𝑗subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖subscript𝑏𝑘𝑖formulae-sequence𝑖12…subscript𝑙0formulae-sequence𝑗12…𝑟subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖12…𝑟\begin{split}&\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime}_{ki,j}=\delta_{j,R_{ki}}\cdot b_{ki};\\ i=1,2,...,l_{0};&j=1,2,...,r,R_{ki}\in\{1,2,...,r\}.\\ \end{split} (16)

or

𝒃k​i,j′=(1−δj,Rk​i)+δj,Rk​i⋅bk​i;i=1,2,…,l0;j=1,2,…,r,Rk​i∈{1,2,…,r}.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝒃′𝑘𝑖𝑗1subscript𝛿𝑗subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖⋅subscript𝛿𝑗subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖subscript𝑏𝑘𝑖formulae-sequence𝑖12…subscript𝑙0formulae-sequence𝑗12…𝑟subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖12…𝑟\begin{split}&\boldsymbol{b}^{\prime}_{ki,j}=(1-\delta_{j,R_{ki}})+\delta_{j,R_{ki}}\cdot b_{ki};\\ i=1,2,...,l_{0};&j=1,2,...,r,R_{ki}\in\{1,2,...,r\}.\\ \end{split} (17)

where Rk​isubscript𝑅𝑘𝑖R_{ki} is an random number Rk​i∈[r]subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖delimited-[]𝑟R_{ki}\in[r] and δj,Rk​isubscript𝛿𝑗subscript𝑅𝑘𝑖\delta_{j,R_{ki}} is the Kronecker delta function.

Then, according to the above rules, by running the QBC algorithm, for each k𝑘k the server would get

1r​l0​∑il0ak​i​bk​ior1r​l0​∑il0ak​i​bk​i+r−1r​l0​∑il0ak​i1𝑟subscript𝑙0superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑙0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑖subscript𝑏𝑘𝑖or1𝑟subscript𝑙0superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑙0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑖subscript𝑏𝑘𝑖𝑟1𝑟subscript𝑙0superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑙0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑖\frac{1}{rl_{0}}\sum_{i}^{l_{0}}a_{ki}b_{ki}\quad\text{or}\quad\frac{1}{rl_{0}}\sum_{i}^{l_{0}}a_{ki}b_{ki}+\frac{r-1}{rl_{0}}\sum_{i}^{l_{0}}a_{ki} (18)

depending on whether the k𝑘k-th client chooses encoding method Eq. 16 or Eq. 17. The difference between the two extracted values is r−1r​l0​∑il0ak​i𝑟1𝑟subscript𝑙0superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑙0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑖\frac{r-1}{rl_{0}}\sum_{i}^{l_{0}}a_{ki} that the server would know. Note that this choice could vary for different client k𝑘k. At the end of the protocol, each client can send an one-bit message via classical channel to the server and let server knows which one was used, after which the server could extract ∑k=1m∑j=1l0ak​j​bk​jsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑙0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑗subscript𝑏𝑘𝑗\sum_{k=1}^{m}\sum_{j=1}^{l_{0}}a_{kj}b_{kj}. This process yields a classical communication 𝒪​(m)𝒪𝑚\mathcal{O}(m).

We remark that at each communication round, the probability that the server samples a specific bit reduces from 1m​l01𝑚subscript𝑙0\frac{1}{ml_{0}} to 1r​m​l01𝑟𝑚subscript𝑙0\frac{1}{rml_{0}} with r>1𝑟1r>1. Even though that r𝑟r-times more communication round will be needed to achieve the same error bound ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon as in the original QBC case, the server would not know which digit encodes the correct bk​isubscript𝑏𝑘𝑖b_{ki} information as here Rk​isubscript𝑅𝑘𝑖R_{ki}s are random numbers. Therefore, the probability that the server successfully gets a specific bit bk​isubscript𝑏𝑘𝑖b_{ki} would be

P=1r​m​l0×rϵ×1r=1r​m​l0​ϵ,𝑃1𝑟𝑚subscript𝑙0𝑟italic-ϵ1𝑟1𝑟𝑚subscript𝑙0italic-ϵP=\frac{1}{rml_{0}}\times\frac{r}{\epsilon}\times\frac{1}{r}=\frac{1}{rml_{0}\epsilon}, (19)

where the second term rϵ𝑟italic-ϵ\frac{r}{\epsilon} is the total number of communication rounds and the third term is 1r1𝑟\frac{1}{r} is due to the randomness in Rk​isubscript𝑅𝑘𝑖R_{ki}.

It’s clear to see that a larger value of r𝑟r corresponds to a decreased probability for the server to successfully extract valuable information from the client through the attack strategy. The flexibility that the client can independently choose encoding method also protects the majority information of 𝒃𝒃\boldsymbol{b}, i.e., the client may choose Eq. 16 to encode data if the majority of 𝒃𝒃\boldsymbol{b} is 111 to decrease the probability that 111s are being detected. Nevertheless, the trade-off for employing this redundant encoding approach compared with the original one in Sec. III.2 manifests as an augmented quantum communication complexity, as the transmitted qubit number goes from log⁡(m​l0)𝑚subscript𝑙0\log(ml_{0}) to log⁡(r​m​l0)𝑟𝑚subscript𝑙0\log(rml_{0}) now. To this end, with the above redundant encoding method, the communication complexity increases logarithmically in r𝑟r, while the probability that server successfully gets a specific bit bk​isubscript𝑏𝑘𝑖b_{ki} decrease polynomially in r𝑟r. ∎

With Theorem 1, we show that one can design a protocol such that the privacy goes polynomially better with a redundant encoding parameter while the communication cost only goes logarithmically or linearly with this parameter.

IV Protocol 2: Incremental learning

The aforementioned protocols entail secure inner product estimation between the server and clients. An alternative approach involves the formulation of protocols with secure weighted gradient summation, ensuring that the server exclusively receives aggregated gradients rather than weighted gradients from individual clients. This concept aligns with the principles of incremental learning, wherein a model or parameter is iteratively trained or updated with new data, assimilating fresh information while preserving knowledge acquired from prior data. In this section, we introduce two such protocols: the first involves secure aggregation through a globally entangled state, while the second is grounded in secure multiparty gradient summation.

IV.1 Secure aggregation based on global entanglement

We start by discussing a secure aggregation protocol using globally entangled state distributed among clients and server (Fig. 2a). Similar as Ref. [39], at each time step and for each parameter to be updated, we consider a global (m𝑚m+1)-qubit GHZ state and each qubit is held by one party. This can be achieved by letting the server prepare an GHZ state locally and then distribute the m𝑚m-qubits to the m𝑚m clients via quantum channels. Alternatively, we can consider each party holds on local qubit and remote entanglement is generated via quantum photonic channels.

Nevertheless, after the preparation of the GHZ state, for a given parameter, the k𝑘k-th client encodes its local weighted gradient information ∇ℒk​(𝜽𝒕)∇subscriptℒ𝑘superscript𝜽𝒕\nabla\mathcal{L}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}}) into the phase of its local qubit by applying a phase gate. This process can be either sequentially or simultaneously. The distributed qubits are then sent back to the server via the quantum channel. The resulting state now reads

12​(|00​…​0⟩s,1,2,…,m+e−i​∑km∇ℒk​(𝜽𝒕)​|11​…​1⟩s,1,2,…,m).12subscriptket00…0𝑠12…𝑚superscript𝑒𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑚∇subscriptℒ𝑘superscript𝜽𝒕subscriptket11…1𝑠12…𝑚\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\ket{00...0}_{s,1,2,...,m}+e^{-i\sum_{k}^{m}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}})}\ket{11...1}_{s,1,2,...,m}). (20)

The server could firstly disentangle the m𝑚m received qubits by performing sequential CNOT gates between the local qubit s𝑠s with the rest m𝑚m qubits, leading to

12​(|0⟩s+e−i​∑km∇ℒk​(𝜽𝒕)​|1⟩s)⊗|0​…​0⟩1,2,…,m.tensor-product12subscriptket0𝑠superscript𝑒𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑚∇subscriptℒ𝑘superscript𝜽𝒕subscriptket1𝑠subscriptket0…012…𝑚\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\ket{0}_{s}+e^{-i\sum_{k}^{m}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}})}\ket{1}_{s})\otimes\ket{0...0}_{1,2,...,m}. (21)

Then, similar as it’s done in a typical Ramsey interferometry experiment [40], the server would need to estimate the phase term ∑im∇ℒi​(𝜽𝒕)superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑚∇subscriptℒ𝑖superscript𝜽𝒕\sum_{i}^{m}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}}) by applying a Hardmard gate on its local qubit followed by projective measurement in computational basis. The probability of getting zero would simply be

Pk​(0)=1+cos⁡(∑km∇ℒk​(𝜽𝒕))2.subscript𝑃𝑘01superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑚∇subscriptℒ𝑘superscript𝜽𝒕2P_{k}(0)=\frac{1+\cos(\sum_{k}^{m}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{k}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}}))}{2}. (22)

The above process is repeated 𝒪​(1ϵ2)𝒪1superscriptitalic-ϵ2\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\epsilon^{2}}) times until the desired error bound ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is met. The procedure is iteratively applied to update all d𝑑d parameters.

We now perform security analysis of the gradient information. As all the local gradient is aggregated in the phase of the GHZ state, the server could not extract the gradient of single clients. Under malicious server setting, in contrast of the semi-honest assumption in Ref. [39], if the GHZ state is distributed by the server, the server could simply prepare the state where only the j𝑗j-th client’s qubit is entangled with the server qubit while others are not entangled, for example,

12​(|0⟩1+|1⟩1)⊗…​12​(|00⟩s,j+|11⟩s,j)⊗…​12​(|0⟩m+|1⟩m).tensor-producttensor-product12subscriptket01subscriptket11…12subscriptket00𝑠𝑗subscriptket11𝑠𝑗…12subscriptket0𝑚subscriptket1𝑚\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\ket{0}_{1}+\ket{1}_{1})\otimes...\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\ket{00}_{s,j}+\ket{11}_{s,j})\otimes...\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}(\ket{0}_{m}+\ket{1}_{m}). (23)

Then, the malicious server would extract the gradient information of client j𝑗j by measuring the phase its local qubit. To tackle this adversary, the GHZ state could be distributed by a trusted client. Alternatively, the GHZ state can be generated by allowing communications among clients. That is, the honest (or honest-but-curious) clients could jointly prepares a m𝑚m-qubit entangled state and then communicate with the server to reach the state Eq. 20.

The total communication complexity for the aforementioned distributed entangled state scenario would be decided by the qubit distribution at each round and number of communication rounds to estimate the phase. Specifically, the total quantum communication cost would read

𝒞G​H​Z=𝒪​(m​dϵ2)subscript𝒞𝐺𝐻𝑍𝒪𝑚𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ2\mathcal{C}_{GHZ}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{md}{\epsilon^{2}}) (24)

with ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon being the error bound for the phase estimation.

IV.2 Secure multiparty gradient summation

We next introduce a gradient-hidden quantum federated learning protocol using phase accumulation and estimation. Inspired by the secure multiparty quantum summation protocol proposed in Ref. [41], we consider the following data encoding method. At each time step t𝑡t, the gradient information for parameter k𝑘k and client l𝑙l is ∇kℒl​(𝜽𝒕)∈{0,δ,2​δ,…,2​π}subscript∇𝑘subscriptℒ𝑙superscript𝜽𝒕0𝛿2𝛿…2𝜋\nabla_{k}\mathcal{L}_{l}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}})\in\{0,\delta,2\delta,...,2\pi\}. Note that here we set the upper bound of each individual gradient to be 2​π2𝜋2\pi for simplicity and the condition can be relaxed.

As shown in the diagram in Fig. 2b, the protocol starts from the first client, who encodes its local gradient information for a given parameter into a hℎh-qubit state |∇ℒ1⟩ket∇subscriptℒ1\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{1}} with h=⌈log⁡(2​π/δ)⌉ℎ2𝜋𝛿h=\lceil\log(2\pi/\delta)\rceil (we consider log⁡(2​π/δ)2𝜋𝛿\log(2\pi/\delta) being an integer for simplity in the following). A subsequent quantum Fourier transform (QFT) would yield the following state

|ψ⟩1=QFT​|∇ℒ1⟩=12h​∑l=12hei​l​δ​∇ℒ1​|l⟩1.subscriptket𝜓1QFTket∇subscriptℒ11superscript2ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑙𝛿∇subscriptℒ1subscriptket𝑙1\ket{\psi}_{1}=\text{QFT}\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{1}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{h}}}\sum_{l=1}^{2^{h}}e^{il\delta\nabla\mathcal{L}_{1}}\ket{l}_{1}. (25)

Then, the first client prepares a hℎh-qubit ancillary state that encodes the same information as |l⟩1subscriptket𝑙1\ket{l}_{1} above. This can be achieved by simply applying CNOT gates between the first hℎh qubits in Eq. 25 and the ancillary hℎh qubits. The resulting state reads

|ψ⟩1,a=12h​∑l=12hei​l​δ​∇ℒ1​|l⟩1​|l⟩1,asubscriptket𝜓1𝑎1superscript2ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑙𝛿∇subscriptℒ1subscriptket𝑙1subscriptket𝑙1𝑎\ket{\psi}_{1,a}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{h}}}\sum_{l=1}^{2^{h}}e^{il\delta\nabla\mathcal{L}_{1}}\ket{l}_{1}\ket{l}_{1,a} (26)

where the subscript a𝑎a denotes ancilla. The first client then sends the hℎh-qubit ancillary state to the second client via quantum communication. Similarly as the first client, the second client would first encode its local gradient information in another hℎh-qubit state |∇ℒ2⟩ket∇subscriptℒ2\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{2}}. In order to perform the summation of ∇ℒ1∇subscriptℒ1\nabla\mathcal{L}_{1} and ∇ℒ2∇subscriptℒ2\nabla\mathcal{L}_{2}, we consider the following operation for the second client: conditioned on the state of the received ancilla qubits, phase gates are applied on the local hℎh qubit, such that the resulting ensemble state reads

|ψ⟩12,a=Ca​Z2​12h​∑l=12hei​l​δ​∇ℒ1​|l⟩1​|l⟩1,a​|∇ℒ2⟩=12h​∑l=12hei​l​δ​(∇ℒ1+∇ℒ2)​|l⟩1​|l⟩1,a​|∇ℒ2⟩.subscriptket𝜓12𝑎subscript𝐶𝑎subscript𝑍21superscript2ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑙𝛿∇subscriptℒ1subscriptket𝑙1subscriptket𝑙1𝑎ket∇subscriptℒ21superscript2ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑙𝛿∇subscriptℒ1∇subscriptℒ2subscriptket𝑙1subscriptket𝑙1𝑎ket∇subscriptℒ2\begin{split}\ket{\psi}_{12,a}&=C_{a}Z_{2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{h}}}\sum_{l=1}^{2^{h}}e^{il\delta\nabla\mathcal{L}_{1}}\ket{l}_{1}\ket{l}_{1,a}\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{2}}\\ &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{h}}}\sum_{l=1}^{2^{h}}e^{il\delta(\nabla\mathcal{L}_{1}+\nabla\mathcal{L}_{2})}\ket{l}_{1}\ket{l}_{1,a}\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{2}}.\\ \end{split} (27)

Note that the local state |∇kℒ2⟩ketsubscript∇𝑘subscriptℒ2\ket{\nabla_{k}\mathcal{L}_{2}} is not entangled with the rest of the system after the above operation. The second client would then pass the received hℎh qubits to the next client and the above process repeats until all the m𝑚m clients encode their local gradient information in the phase:

|ψ⟩123​…​m,a=12h​∑l=12hei​l​δ​∑im∇ℒi|l⟩1​|l⟩1,a​|∇ℒ2⟩…​|∇ℒm−1⟩​|∇ℒm⟩.subscriptket𝜓123…𝑚𝑎1superscript2ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑙𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑚∇subscriptℒ𝑖subscriptket𝑙1subscriptket𝑙1𝑎ket∇subscriptℒ2…ket∇subscriptℒ𝑚1ket∇subscriptℒ𝑚\begin{split}\ket{\psi}_{123...m,a}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{h}}}\sum_{l=1}^{2^{h}}e^{il\delta\sum_{i}^{m}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}}&\ket{l}_{1}\ket{l}_{1,a}\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{2}}\\ &...\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{m-1}}\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{m}}.\\ \end{split} (28)

The m𝑚m-th cient would return the ancillary qubits back to the first client, who will subsequently perform verification on the states to detect potential dishonesty of the involved parities. Specifically, the first client would first uncompute the ancillary qubits with CNOT gates, leading to

|ψ⟩123​…​m,a′=12h​∑l=12hei​l​δ​∑im∇ℒi|l⟩1​|0⟩1,a​|∇ℒ2⟩…​|∇ℒm−1⟩​|∇ℒm⟩.subscriptket𝜓123…𝑚superscript𝑎′1superscript2ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑙𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑚∇subscriptℒ𝑖subscriptket𝑙1subscriptket01𝑎ket∇subscriptℒ2…ket∇subscriptℒ𝑚1ket∇subscriptℒ𝑚\begin{split}\ket{\psi}_{123...m,a^{{}^{\prime}}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{h}}}\sum_{l=1}^{2^{h}}e^{il\delta\sum_{i}^{m}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}}&\ket{l}_{1}\ket{0}_{1,a}\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{2}}\\ &...\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{m-1}}\ket{\nabla\mathcal{L}_{m}}.\\ \end{split} (29)

Then the ancillary qubits are measured. In the absence of malicious client that tries to extract the phase information of previous clients and perform projective measurements on the ancillary qubits in computational basis, the measurement should yield 0 for all the hℎh qubits. For example, if a malicious client applies inverse QFT on the ancillary qubits to extract the aggregated phase, the first client can detect this anomaly, given that the ancillary qubits cannot be reset to |0⟩1,asubscriptket01𝑎\ket{0}_{1,a} in such a scenario.

Upon the verification, the first client would send the |l⟩1subscriptket𝑙1\ket{l}_{1} state to the server, who can then apply inverse QFT to extract the accumulated gradient information.

|ψ⟩s=QFT−1​12h​∑l=12hei​l​δ​∑im∇ℒi​|l⟩1=|∑im∇ℒimod2​π⟩1subscriptket𝜓𝑠superscriptQFT11superscript2ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑙𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑚∇subscriptℒ𝑖subscriptket𝑙1subscriptketmodulosuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑚∇subscriptℒ𝑖2𝜋1\begin{split}\ket{\psi}_{s}&=\text{QFT}^{-1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{h}}}\sum_{l=1}^{2^{h}}e^{il\delta\sum_{i}^{m}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}}\ket{l}_{1}\\ &=\ket{\sum_{i}^{m}\nabla\mathcal{L}_{i}\mod 2\pi}_{1}\\ \end{split} (30)

With the state |∑im∇kℒimod2​π⟩1subscriptketmodulosuperscriptsubscript𝑖𝑚subscript∇𝑘subscriptℒ𝑖2𝜋1\ket{\sum_{i}^{m}\nabla_{k}\mathcal{L}_{i}\mod 2\pi}_{1} outlined above, the server could perform model aggregation and update the model accordingly. The same protocol applies for other parameters to be updated and different time windows.

We remark that as the state received by the server is 12h​∑l=12hei​l​δ​∑im∇kℒi​|l⟩11superscript2ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑙1superscript2ℎsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑙𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑚subscript∇𝑘subscriptℒ𝑖subscriptket𝑙1\frac{1}{\sqrt{2^{h}}}\sum_{l=1}^{2^{h}}e^{il\delta\sum_{i}^{m}\nabla_{k}\mathcal{L}_{i}}\ket{l}_{1} and the gradient aggregation has already been performed incrementally, the server could not extract the local gradient information held by individual clients. Moreover, the verification procedure could ensure that a malicious client could not simply perform measurement on the phase of the received qubits to extract the previously aggregated gradient information. To this end, the protocol relies on one trusted client node that can prepare the entangled state in Eq. 26 and send the final hℎh-qubit state to the server. The efficiency of this incremental learning protocol might be improved by pre-assigning clients into multiple batches in which there are at least one trusted node.

We now discuss the quantum communication cost of the designed protocol. As discussed above, the hℎh-qubit states are transmitted among all the m𝑚m clients for each parameter to be updated. For p𝑝p iterations of the process that are needed to yield a standard error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon on the phase, the communication complexity of this secure multiparty summation protocol is given by

𝒞S​M​S=(m+1)×d×h×p=𝒪​(m​dϵ​log⁡mϵ)subscript𝒞𝑆𝑀𝑆𝑚1𝑑ℎ𝑝𝒪𝑚𝑑italic-ϵ𝑚italic-ϵ\mathcal{C}_{SMS}=(m+1)\times d\times h\times p=\mathcal{O}(\frac{md}{\epsilon}\log\frac{m}{\epsilon}) (31)

where the log⁡(mϵ)𝑚italic-ϵ\log(\frac{m}{\epsilon}) term is associated with the error that comes from assigning ∇kℒ​(𝜽𝒕)∈{0,δ,2​δ,…,2​π}subscript∇𝑘ℒsuperscript𝜽𝒕0𝛿2𝛿…2𝜋\nabla_{k}\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta^{t}})\in\{0,\delta,2\delta,...,2\pi\}.

Alternatively, one may consider encoding all the d𝑑d gradient information in a superposition state with ⌈log⁡d⌉𝑑\lceil\log d\rceil qubits to reduce communication cost in terms of number of parameters d𝑑d. However, as the server would need to update the d𝑑d parameters separately, at least d𝑑d samplings are required to query the encoded gradient information hence the total communication complexity in d𝑑d would still be 𝒪~​(d)~𝒪𝑑\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(d).

V Discussions

We remark that the above protocols leveraging quantum communication can be integrated with common quantum cryptography techniques [30, 42, 10, 43] to be secure against external attacks. As an example, we consider using decoy state [42] to detect eavesdropping attacks: when a quantum state with n𝑛n data qubits is sent to another party via a quantum channel during the QFL protocols, decoy states are randomly inserted and sent along with data qubits.

More specifically, when a n𝑛n-qubit state is transmitted, we consider nd=𝒪​(n)subscript𝑛𝑑𝒪𝑛n_{d}=\mathcal{O}(n) decoy qubits that are randomly drawn from {|0⟩,|1⟩,|+⟩,|−⟩}ket0ket1ketket\{\ket{0},\ket{1},\ket{+},\ket{-}\} by the sender. The receiver receives the data and decoy qubits from the quantum channel, as well as positions and encoding basis of decoy qubits from a separated classical channel. After measuring the decoy qubits in the instructed basis, the receiver transmits the measurement results to the sender, who will then calculate the error rate and detect the potential existence of external eavesdropper. In this simple case, for a given decoy state, the probability that the eavesdropper performs a measurement on it without being detected is simply 3434\frac{3}{4} and the probability drops exponentially when there are ndsubscript𝑛𝑑n_{d} uncorrelated decoy qubits. Advanced decoy-state quantum key distribution techniques [10] can be implemented to enhance the protocol’s resilience against third-party attacks.

In this scenario, while the protocol demonstrates the capability to detect eavesdropper attacks, it incurs an additional cost in communication complexity. Specifically, there is an extra classical and quantum communication cost of 𝒪​(nd)𝒪subscript𝑛𝑑\mathcal{O}(n_{d}) between each sender and receiver pair.

It is important to emphasize that the proposed QFL protocols do not depend on a variational quantum circuit for gradient generation. Instead, gradient information can be produced using a classical neural network, thereby reducing the quantum capability demands on both the server and clients. Furthermore, in contrast to numerous classical federated learning algorithms that may face a trade-off between privacy loss and utility loss [44], the quantum protocols presented in this study do not compromise privacy for diminished utility, such as reduced accuracy.

VI Conclusion

In conclusion, we design gradient-hidden protocols for secure federated learning to protect against gradient inversion attacks and safeguard clients’ local information. The proposed algorithms involve quantum communication among a server and clients, and we analyze both privacy and communication costs. The secure inner product estimation protocol based on BQBC relies on transmitting a logarithmic number of qubits to reduce the information server could query. We devise an efficient redundant encoding method to improve privacy further. For the incremental learning protocols, we consider both phase encoding based on globally entangled state and secure multi-party summation of gradient information to prevent the server from learning individual gradients from clients. We further discuss the quantum and classical communication costs involved in each protocol.

Our present study suggests numerous potential avenues for future research. Firstly, while the proposed protocols primarily address adversaries in the form of a malicious or honest-but-curious server, there is a need to develop secure protocols tailored to scenarios involving a dishonest majority, encompassing malicious clients [45, 46]. Secondly, the protocols proposed herein can be extended and applied to other secure distributed quantum computing tasks, such as quantum e-voting protocols [47, 48]. Furthermore, our work would motivate subsequent efforts aimed at achieving quantum communication advantages while preserving privacy advantages over classical counterparts in practical distributed machine learning tasks [49, 6]. To this end, our work sheds light on designing efficient quantum communication-assisted distributed machine learning algorithms, studying quantum inherent privacy mechanisms, and paves the way for secure distributed quantum computing protocols.

Appendix A Gradient-inversion attack in federated learning

In this section, we expand upon the argument presented in Sec. II.2, namely a major data leakage issue with the standard classical federated learning approach. This vulnerability arises from the susceptibility to a gradient inversion attack, wherein an honest-but-curious server can successfully reconstruct the original data from the received gradients [18, 17]. Here we analyze an example case by looking at the vulnerability of recovering averaged data information where the model considered for training is the fully connected neural network layer. To simplify the analysis, we consider a dense linear layer containing 𝐱=x1​⋯​xn𝐱subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑛\mathbf{x}=x_{1}\cdots x_{n} as input and y∈𝒞𝑦𝒞y\in\mathcal{C} as output 333We represent the y𝑦y as y1​⋯​y|𝒞|subscript𝑦1⋯subscript𝑦𝒞y_{1}\cdots y_{|\mathcal{C}|} such that y=ci𝑦subscript𝑐𝑖y=c_{i} implies yi=1subscript𝑦𝑖1y_{i}=1 and rest being zero. This gives us |𝒞|𝒞|\mathcal{C}| number of finite output classes. As an example, for |𝒞|=3𝒞3|\mathcal{C}|=3, the set 𝒞={a1:100,a2:010,a3:001}𝒞conditional-setsubscript𝑎1:100subscript𝑎2010subscript𝑎3:001\mathcal{C}=\{a_{1}:100,a_{2}:010,a_{3}:001\}., where the dense layer is oj=∑i=1nwi​j​xi+bjsubscript𝑜𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑏𝑗o_{j}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_{ij}x_{i}+b_{j}. Given a known y𝑦y, 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} can be inverted successfully, and any additional hidden layers can be inverted by back-propagation.

Consider a typical classification architecture that uses softmax activation function, pk=eok∑jeojsubscript𝑝𝑘superscript𝑒subscript𝑜𝑘subscript𝑗superscript𝑒subscript𝑜𝑗p_{k}=\frac{e^{o_{k}}}{\sum_{j}e^{o_{j}}} to create the model label y​(𝐰,𝐛)=carg max​(pk)𝑦𝐰𝐛subscript𝑐arg maxsubscript𝑝𝑘y(\mathbf{w},\mathbf{b})=c_{\text{arg max}(p_{k})} (here k𝑘k is the index for label class), followed by the cross entropy to obtain the cost value,

ℒ​(p,y)=−∑k|𝒞|yk​log⁡pkℒ𝑝𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑘𝒞subscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘\mathcal{L}(p,y)=-\sum_{k}^{|\mathcal{C}|}y_{k}\log p_{k} (32)

where |𝒞|𝒞|\mathcal{C}| is the number of output classes. The derivative of pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} with respect to each ojsubscript𝑜𝑗o_{j} is,

∂pk∂oj={pk​(1−pj),k=j−pk​pj,k≠jsubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑜𝑗casesotherwisesubscript𝑝𝑘1subscript𝑝𝑗𝑘𝑗otherwisesubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑝𝑗𝑘𝑗\frac{\partial p_{k}}{\partial o_{j}}=\begin{cases}&p_{k}(1-p_{j}),\hskip 5.69054ptk=j\\ &-p_{k}p_{j},\hskip 5.69054ptk\neq j\end{cases} (33)

Now we can calculate the derivative of the cost function with respect to the weights and biases via backpropagation,

∂ℒ∂wi,j=k=(pj−yj)​xi,ℒsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗𝑘subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial w_{i,j=k}}=(p_{j}-y_{j})x_{i}, (34)
∂ℒ∂bj=k=pj−yj.ℒsubscript𝑏𝑗𝑘subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial b_{j=k}}=p_{j}-y_{j}. (35)

From this, it can be seen that the number of gradient equations shared with the server would be n​|𝒞|+|𝒞|𝑛𝒞𝒞n|\mathcal{C}|+|\mathcal{C}| while the number of unknowns is n+|𝒞|𝑛𝒞n+|\mathcal{C}|. For example, from the above equations, it can be seen see that xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} can be found from any j𝑗j, using,

∂ℒ∂wi,j=k/∂ℒ∂bj=k=xiℒsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗𝑘ℒsubscript𝑏𝑗𝑘subscript𝑥𝑖\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial w_{i,j=k}}/\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial b_{j=k}}=x_{i} (36)

In the above setting we saw that for batch size B=1𝐵1B=1, the number of unknowns is less than the number of equations and thus the unknowns can be trivially recovered from the system of equations generated by the dense linear layer of the neural network.

It turns out there is a feasible attack even if we consider the mini-batch size training with B>1𝐵1B>1. Here, the client trains with the inputs Samp:=[(𝐱κ,yκ)κ∈Samp]assignSampdelimited-[]subscriptsubscript𝐱𝜅subscript𝑦𝜅𝜅Samp\text{Samp}:=[(\mathbf{x}_{\kappa},y_{\kappa})_{\kappa\in\text{Samp}}] and only shares the averaged gradient information (over the data points with B=|Samp|𝐵SampB=|\text{Samp}|) with the server,

∂ℒ∂wi,j=k=1B​∑κ∈Samp(pκ​j−yκ​j)​xκ​i,ℒsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗𝑘1𝐵subscript𝜅Sampsubscript𝑝𝜅𝑗subscript𝑦𝜅𝑗subscript𝑥𝜅𝑖\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial w_{i,j=k}}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\kappa\in\text{Samp}}(p_{\kappa j}-y_{\kappa j})x_{\kappa i}, (37)
∂ℒ∂bj=k=1B​∑κ∈Samppκ​j−yκ​jℒsubscript𝑏𝑗𝑘1𝐵subscript𝜅Sampsubscript𝑝𝜅𝑗subscript𝑦𝜅𝑗\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial b_{j=k}}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{\kappa\in\text{Samp}}p_{\kappa j}-y_{\kappa j} (38)

In this scenario, the number of equations shared is still n​|𝒞|+|𝒞|𝑛𝒞𝒞n|\mathcal{C}|+|\mathcal{C}|, whereas the number of unknowns is now B​(n+|𝒞|)𝐵𝑛𝒞B(n+|\mathcal{C}|). Thus the number of unknowns can now exceed the number of equations, resulting in no unique solution for the server when attempting to solve the system of equations. Even in the case that a unique solution exists, numerical optimization can be challenging. However, In cases where the softmax follows the cross-entropy, the authors in  [18] demonstrate that an accurate direct solution can be achieved in many instances, even when B≫1much-greater-than𝐵1B\gg 1. This is attributed to the demixing property across the batch, facilitating the server’s ease in retrieving the data points in Samp.

Appendix B Protection mechanisms in classical federated learning

To safeguard clients’ data from diverse adversaries, including gradient inversion attacks, classical federated learning protocols have implemented multiple protection mechanisms. In this context, we provide a concise review of these techniques.

Homomorphic Encryption (HE) [51, 22] stands out as a widely employed encryption technique for privacy protection, enabling the aggregation of local gradient information directly on encrypted data without the need for decryption. However, the practical application of HE faces challenges due to the substantial computational and communication overhead it introduces, particularly for large models [52].

Another prevalent technique involves the application of differential privacy [23, 53, 54, 55, 56], wherein Laplace noise or Gaussian noise is typically added to gradient information. While this method is straightforward and minimally impacts communication and computation costs, it may compromise privacy and result in diminished model utility.

Additionally, secret sharing techniques [57, 31] have been developed to distribute a secret among a group of participants, such as sharing local gradient information with the server using secret sharing among clients. Nevertheless, this approach necessitates extensive message exchange, incurring a communication overhead that may be impractical in many federated learning settings. A concrete example of such techniques is presented in Sec. III.1 of the main text.
